quoteFirst: While these events were transpiring on our right, the enemy, in formidable numbers, made repeated and desperate assaults upon the left of our line.
quoteLast: , having massed his troops under cover of the houses of Fredericksburg, he moved forward in strong columns to seize Marye's and Willis's Hills. All his batteries on the Stafford Heights directed their fire upon the positions occupied by our artillery, with a view to silence it, and cover the movement of the infantry.
title: The Rise and Fall of the Confederate Government, Volume 2
author: Davis, Jefferson, 1808-1889

quoteTime: About eleven o’clock in the morning
quoteLast: we induced our host to make a little investigation of the police situation for us. He returned after an hour with the none too encouraging news that two men who were believed to be the St. Catharines looters had been traced to Buffalo.

quoteLast: next morning.

quoteTime: about eleven o'clock in the morning
quoteLast: of the day on which he died, Huber's lich was interred in the gruesome cemetery of plain black crosses on the hillside, a mile beyond the town, I officiating by throwing the last few shovelfuls of dirt on his eternal resting place. The town authorities took charge of his possessions and notified his employers who knew the address of his relations in Stettin.

quoteFirst: Petersburg road, Montbrun along that to Moscow, while Bruyère’s division of Nansouty’s corps was ordered to support Ney. Evidently Napoleon had no certainty as to the precise direction of Barclay’s retreat, and so far the Russian general’s delay on the 18th had justified itself.

quoteFirst: I AM come here after six days.  I set out on Monday last, and got here to-day
quoteLast: .  A noble rider, fais! and all the ships and people went off yesterday with a rare wind.  This was told me, to my comfort, upon my arrival.
title: The Journal to Stella
author: Swift, Jonathan, 1667-1745; Aitken, George Atherton, 1860-1917 [Editor]

quoteFirst: The feed was so scarce that we were kept running all night. I was so completely worn out next day that at
quoteLast: I sought rest by dropping out of the command and hiding from the rearguard behind a clump of brush that grew on a sand knoll. No sooner had I laid down than I fell into a sound slumber, oblivious to all danger.
title: Life of a Pioneer: Being the Autobiography of James S. Brown
author: Brown, James S. (James Stephens), 1828-1902

quoteFirst: We drank our tea and turned in. At
quoteLast: we awoke and breakfasted on some things we had brought with us from East Cape. It was now snowing very hard and there was no use in setting out, so we decided to wait until night. At six P. M.
title: The last voyage of the Karluk

quoteFirst: The morning dawned in the inevitable white blanket of mist which now always seemed to accompany our attacks. Till
quoteLast: it was impossible to see more than a few yards ahead, and it was with the greatest difficulty that the Tanks kept their direction. If, however, the mist was confusing to us, it was doubly so to the enemy.
title: The Tank Corps

quoteFirst: The whirlwind lasted about an hour. No explosions were heard till the whirlwind had ceased, at
quoteLast: From midnight till the evening of the 11th, they continued without intermission; after that time their violence moderated, and they were only heard at intervals, but the explosions did not cease entirely until the 15th of July. Of the whole villages of Tomboro, Tempo containing about forty inhabitants is the only one remaining.

quoteFirst: Believing bloodletting to be necessary, he procured a bleeder who took from his arm twelve or fourteen ounces of blood, but he would not permit a messenger to be despatched for his family physician until the appearance of day.
